risks.Risk Description: Cyber security is flagged as the number one risk in our analysis for 2023 and has remained in the top two risks facing the sector in the last three years. Given the significant number and severity of cyber security incidents experienced by the sector in the last few years, the sector remains an attractive target for cyber security attackers.

Risk Driver.Driver Description: The sector remains an attractive target for cyber security attackers and the likelihood of state sponsored attacks could increase.

Risk Driver.Driver Name: Underinvestment in technical controls and staff
Risk Driver.Driver Description: Many institutions have historically not invested in technical IT controls and dedicated cyber security staff.
The IT environment across institutions is diverse and has been built up in a piecemeal fashion over a number of years.
Shadow IT is common and widespread across many institutions.
Recruiting talented cyber security staff is challenging and costly.
Obtaining insurance to transfer at least part of the cyber security risk is increasingly difficult.

risks.Trend: Cyber security has remained in the top two risks facing the sector for the last three years and is flagged as the number one risk in 2023.

risks.Risk Description: Institutions are worried about the impact of climate change and the work required to meet Net Zero targets, particularly around the difficulty of calculating and reducing scope three emissions.

Risk Driver.Driver Description: Scope three indirect emissions have proved much more difficult to calculate than scope one and two emissions.
Some institutions have found it challenging to obtain the funding for plans to reduce carbon emissions and gaining buy-in from the whole organisation.
The estate has a number of old buildings which were not built with sustainability in mind.

risks.Trend: This is the first time sustainability, environment and climate change has appeared in the top five risks for 2023.

risks.Risk Description: All of the risk registers we reviewed included risks around the medium to long term financial sustainability of institutions, balancing increasing costs with flat revenue streams.

Risk Driver.Driver Description: Rising energy costs are increasing the institutional cost base.
Inflation on non-pay expense is putting additional strain on budgets.
Staff costs are rising to support staff through the cost of living crisis.
Employer contributions to pensions have risen, impacting long-term sustainability.
Undergraduate tuition fees are capped at £9,250 until at least 2024/25.
The total number of home UK undergraduate applicants dropped by approximately 2% in 2022/23.
Competition for international students is increasing exponentially.

Risk Recommendations: Better understand the drivers of the cost base and the relative income generated on a granular level (e.g., course by course).
Assess how new income streams will contribute to the overall financial position.
Evaluate whether investments will generate a sufficient return within an appropriate timeframe.
Ensure effective controls over procurement, contract management, and budgetary performance.
Consider bold decisions such as course closures or stopping certain activities to improve resilience.
Seek out innovative ways in which income can be generated.
risks.Trend: Medium to long term financial sustainability has become a greater concern in 2023, appearing in 100% of risk registers.

risks.Risk Name: Infrastructure - university estates and technology capacity / capability
risks.Risk Description: With many universities operating in aging estates and a lack of funding into physical facilities in recent years, infrastructure was identified as a new challenge in 2023, exacerbated by historic underinvestment.

Risk Driver.Driver Description: Many institutions operate old buildings not designed with sustainability or modern teaching needs in mind.
There has been a historic lack of planning and investment across the estate.
Backlog in estate maintenance due to the pandemic disruption over the past three years.
Restructuring of campus layouts in response to new blended and innovative delivery models.
Concerns about future energy usage as estates become more energy-intensive.
Increasing demand from students for education in innovative ways affects space utilisation.

Risk Recommendations: Conduct data-driven analysis of space utilisation to inform strategic decision making.
Redistribute and right-size space, and consider selling spare capacity to raise additional finance.
Explore self-generation of energy and investment in green energy supplies.
risks.Trend: Infrastructure risks have significantly increased in relevance in 2023, appearing as a new top theme.

risks.Risk Description: The sector must adapt to a new digital age, integrating systems and implementing blended learning while maintaining quality; failure to improve digital capabilities may lead to operational inefficiencies and reputational damage.

Risk Driver.Driver Description: Digital infrastructure investment has historically been neglected due to perceived cost and complexity.
Moves to the cloud are both costly and technically challenging, with increased costs and delays.
Diversification of data, software, systems and users without centralised controls increases risk.
The advent of AI technologies brings a new set of academic and operational risks.

risks.Trend: In the past year, risks around digital infrastructure have increased significantly.

risks.Risk Description: Attracting and keeping the best people is pivotal; inability to recruit and retain diverse, high calibre staff leads to increased workloads, turnover and impacts on the student experience.

Risk Driver.Driver Description: The current national dispute includes pay, precarious contracts, workloads and the gender/BAME pay gap, contributing to strike action.
Inability to attract and retain staff is leading to increased workloads and a reduced student experience.
Ongoing USS pension issues are driving staff unrest.
Competition to recruit talented staff is challenging and costly.

risks.Risk Description: Government and Department for Education policy shapes the sector’s risk environment; failure to anticipate and respond to policy changes may impact recruitment, funding and strategic goals.

Risk Driver.Driver Description: Government policy changes, including those affecting student recruitment and funding, directly influence university operations.
Increased regulatory burden from bodies such as the Office for Students.
Levelling-up ambitions will impact how research funding is directed in future.
Changes in immigration policy could radically impact long-term sector viability.

risks.Risk Description: Volatile recruitment market, including a 2% drop in home UK undergraduate applicants in 2022/23 and increased global competition, risks missing enrollment targets and financial impacts.

Risk Driver.Driver Description: Home UK undergraduate applicants dropped by approximately 2%.
Changes in immigration policy and international relations may affect recruitment.
Growing global competition for international students.
Increase in applications from Indian and Nigerian students, offset by a decrease in Chinese student numbers.

risks.Trend: Home UK undergraduate applications fell by around 2% in 2022/23.

risks.Risk Description: Failure to deliver a high quality, inclusive student experience across the lifecycle can negatively affect satisfaction, academic achievement, National Student Survey results and league table rankings.

Risk Driver.Driver Description: Failure to adapt teaching and learning methods to meet the needs of large and diverse cohorts.
Hybrid/blended learning reduces campus interactions, making it harder to provide support.
Lack of resources to support growing student numbers.
Failure to develop a vibrant student voice and community undermines engagement.

risks.Trend: Student experience remains the most common risk but has dropped out of the top five in impact and likelihood.

risks.Risk Description: Failure to offer suitable support on health and wellbeing, including mental health, and to prevent harassment and sexual misconduct, risks student safety and regulatory non-compliance.

Risk Driver.Driver Description: An increasing number of students are suffering with their mental health.
Hybrid/blended learning makes it harder for institutions to spot those in need of support.
Risk of failure to prevent and address harassment and sexual misconduct.
Insufficient student welfare and pastoral support services.

risks.Risk Description: Inability to deliver impactful, high quality research, build strategic alliances, secure funding and maintain research integrity threatens reputation and financial sustainability.

Risk Driver.Driver Description: Insufficient research grant funding to deliver a critical mass of world leading research.
Failure to forge strategic alliances and academic partnerships.
Failure to strengthen research culture, quality and standards.
Risk of constraints on academic freedom due to external pressures.

risks.Risk Description: Failure to deliver on an approved Access & Participation plan, including failing to recruit, retain and maintain diverse student profiles and to remove attainment gaps, risks culture, morale and reputation.
Failure to ensure that our operating model adapts as needed to support academic teaching and research objectives may limit the ability to deliver strategic goals.
Risk of failure to lead and manage the substantial amount of technical, educational and people-related change required by strategic initiatives.
Failure to develop a critical mass of partnerships aligned to strategic objectives makes the university uncompetitive in innovation, enterprise and revenue generation.
